Award.AwardTitle: CC-NIE Integration: Creation of an Institutional Cyberinfrastructure to Enable Researcher-Oriented, Federated Environment for Large, Collaborative Science Projects

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Wide spread adoption of cyberinfrastructure advances has been a challenge to researchers mainly due to the traditional cyberinfrastructure equipment, policies and engineering practices at campuses. This University of Missouri (MU) project enables a 100 GB connection extending across the state of Missouri from St. Louis through Columbia to Kansas City directly on the I2 Innovation Network backbone. It includes wide-area network experimentation to seamlessly integrate MU's cyberinfrastructure and Science DMZ with a remote campus (Ohio State University) cyberinfrastructure. It also involves integrating advanced technologies (e.g., 100Gbps connectivity, perfSONAR, OpenFlow, RoCE/iWARP) relevant to the use cases of diverse researchers at MU and OSU.

Building CI in this environment requires authentication, authorization, and policy-limited access to resources. The project engages all three elements of Internet2's Innovation Network: Software Defined Networking (SDN), OpenFlow and Federated Identity. The University of Missouri is modifying its existing cyberinfrastructure to accommodate advanced tools enabled by OpenFlow and SDN. The existing science DMZ is compatible with the Innovation Network Science DMZ. MU is also customizing Shibboleth Federated Identity Management services
to provide fine-grained authorization and access to specific resources. The entitlement server implements policy that controls the bandwidth consumed by individual users or programs. The project broadly disseminates research results through publication on the project web site, disseminated through various regional and national conferences, and journal articles. Open source software from the project will also be made available.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ability for researchers to collaborate in the current world of advanced networking is vital to make progress on various kinds of research problems in all areas of research endeavors. The purpose of this research project was to create an advanced networking infrastructure that connected the University of Missouri with research collaborators spread widely around the United States. This was done in concert with the Internet2 Advanced Networking Project to seek improved ways of overcoming various speed limitations with network protocols that were developed more than 50 years ago. Several use cases were defined to work on research problems in the areas of bioinformatics, visualization, medicine and activities that require very large data transfers, including some with severe time constraints, in order to be able to acquire, process and report results of vital interest to the researchers. This entails developing new protocols and methodologies to be able to use current state of the art technologies that are not bounded by speed limitations imposed by the networking services available to the public and research community at large. Several graduate students were trained during the research activities, and the trainees included several female students. Several peer-reviewed publications have been archived based on the project activities, and presentations at high performance computing and networking community related conference venues have been provided to share knowledge and experiences from the project activities.

Working with the Internet2 Advanced Networking Group that maintains a national network operating with data transfer capacity of 100 billion (100G) bits of data per second, the project team at Missouri worked with collaborators at Ohio State University, Clemson University, the GENI project, Google Fiber project, the iPlant project and others to connect the University to the backbone network of the Internet2 network. It took almost two years to build out the needed fiber paths to make the connections to the Internet2 network before the research use cases could be developed and tested. The outcome of this effort was that the connections were made and the ability to work on previously difficult to impossible problems could be successfully accomplished. 

While 100G seems to be fast in today's environment of kilobit and megabit transmissions, it is still too slow to work on various scientific problems that require the efficient movement of data from one location to another. Recent predictions have been made that the total quantity of data communication done today will require up to 25 times that amount of capacity in just the next five or so years. The work done on this project is one part of the necessary efforts to build the capability and capacity to accommodate the exponential growth of data transfer needs not only for research, but for the public as well.

During the course of this project, the project team had to be flexible in developing the connection routes for the network infrastructure that connected the University to the Internet2 infrastructure since the access to needed fiber paths were unavailable in a timely or cost effective manner. Therefore other plans had to be developed and implemented to make the connections operational. Fortunately pathways that utilized both University fiber resources as well as cooperation with the Internet2 organization's national fiber resources were found and put to use. In addition, due to the newness of some of the technologies involved, the architecture of the entire Internet2 Advanced Networking environment was changed. Just recently the connections from the University to Internet2 were realigned to accommodate the revised architecture. This need for flexibility is ever present when working with new technologies that get revised and refined in order to continually keep pace with the changing landscape of these technologies.
